Award.AwardTitle: DIMENSIONS: Collaborative: DIversification Dynamics of Multitrophic Interactions in Tropical Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
How is biodiversity generated and maintained? Much evidence suggests that parasites play an important role in both the origin and the maintenance of biological diversity. This project focuses on one of the most diverse groups of organisms on the planet: herbivorous insects, their parasites, and their microbes. The project targets three economically important groups of organisms: plants in the pumpkin/cucumber family, true fruit flies that attack these plants, and parasitic wasps that kill the flies. These wasps belong to a highly diverse and little studied group of species. Each wasp species can kill only one fly species; wasps attacking the "wrong" species of fly die. These bi-directional lethal interactions may be mediated by microbes (in wasps, flies, or both), by traits of flies' immune systems, or both. This project is designed to uncover the mechanisms (evolutionary, ecological, and immunological) affecting interactions that may help explain the diversity of life. Many species of true fruit flies are major agricultural pests; this project will greatly increase knowledge about factors contributing to their susceptibility to parasitoids.

The project tests hypotheses that predict that: 1) defenses of parasites and their hosts affect diversification rates; 2) mechanisms of virulence differ among lineages, and 3) selection arising from predator-prey interactions can affect rates of species-formation. To discover and identify mechanisms of diversification, participants will generate and analyze molecular 1) high-resolution genetic data, multiple nuclear loci, and mtCOI haplotypes to delineate species, and resolve deeper phylogenetic relationships; 2) microsatellites and ddRAD-seq markers to discover and quantify fine-scale genetic diversity within and among populations; 3) phylogenies and field experiments to test hypotheses about mechanisms generating and controlling diversity on ancient, recent, and contemporary timescales. Undergraduate students from all participating colleges and universities will participate in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

The project focuses on a species-rich tropical community of plants (Cucurbitaceae), herbivores (newly discovered species of tephritid fruit flies in the genus Blepharoneura), and their
predators (parasitic wasps in the genus Bellopius) and tests the hypothesis that highly specific lethal interactions between herbivores and predators may explain patterns of diversity and diversification. Experiments were designed to test the hypothesis that lethal interactions may be mediated by microbes (in wasps, flies, or both), by traits of flies’ immune systems, or both. First, techniques were developed to characterize known examples of endogenous viruses associated with parasitic wasps that are delivered during parasitism and are successful for wasps’ parasitism success. The genes of viral origin within parasitic wasp genomes were catalogued for two species with independently-derived endogenous viruses. Next, a method was developed to discover previously unknown examples of endogenous viruses in parasitic wasp genomes, and was successful in identifying novel cases of the acquisition of viral genes into wasp genomes that may have a strong impact upon their ability to parasitize herbivorous host insects. This method was applied to data generated from Bellopius wasps and no genetic evidence for endogenous viruses was found, suggesting that this type of microbial interaction does not the govern lethal interactions between wasps and their hosts in this system. A second major activity was characterizing the bacterial community present in wasps and flies in this system. Although intracellular bacteria known as Wolbachia were identified in both wasps and flies, the pattern of infection prevalence and microbial diversity did not correlate with patterns of lethal interactions between these species. Therefore, we were able to conclude that microbes are not likely to play a role in the lethal interactions between Bellopius wasps and Blepharoneura flies in a species-rich tropical community.

This project has resulted in two peer-reviewed publications, one publication available on a pre-print server, and a master’s thesis publication. Results were also presented at a national entomology conference (Entomological Society for America meeting).

 

Broader impacts:

In total, this award has provided training in insect cell and molecular biology and bioinformatics for 14 undergraduate students, 5 technical staff, 9 graduate students, five postdoctoral fellows and 1 visiting scientist from five different institutions. Participants in training were diverse and included women (56% of trainees) and under-represented minorities (21% of trainees). This award supported a graduate student for the completion of a Master’s thesis project, and a visiting under-represented minority undergraduate student from Cornell College for a two-month summer internship. The training provided was relevant to the field of study and also broadly to the fields of applied science, agriculture (focus species were important insect pests or biological control agents), and medicine (animal-microbe interactions). Two informal inter-institutional workshops provided training in insect cell and molecular biology, using lab-reared insects to learn how to practice in a field setting. Another inter-institutional workshop in bioinformatics allowed participants to formally learn key skills for the manipulation of sequence data. An online survey assessed the impact of the bioinformatics workshop and revealed strong gains in competencies post-workshop compared to pre-existing competencies. Informally, workshop participants shared research results and expertise in poster presentations and on a publicly available blog.
